title: Rampage cruise in delayed home opener
text:
Rampage cruise in delayed home opener By John Whisler Updated 11:46 pm, Saturday, October 24, 2015 Photo: Ron Cortes, Freelancer / For The San Antonio / Express-News Image 1 of / 1 Close Image 1 of 1 Rampage's Maxim Noreau takes out Stockton's Freddie Hamilton in first period action in American Hockey League home opener for San Antonio on Saturday, October 24, 2015. Rampage's Maxim Noreau takes out Stockton's Freddie Hamilton in first period action in American Hockey League home opener for San Antonio on Saturday, October 24, 2015. Photo: Ron Cortes, Freelancer / For The San Antonio / Express-News Rampage cruise in delayed home opener 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
Multi-point nights by a pair of rookies highlighted a successful home opener for the Rampage on Saturday night at the AT&T Center. 
Finnish winger Mikko Rantanen — just 18 years old — scored his first North American pro goal and added an assist, while defenseman Chris Bigras ’ two-point night included his first pro goal as the Rampage beat the Stockton Heat 5-1. 
The game was delayed one hour because of problems with the ice. 
For more, visit ExpressNews.com 
Rantanen, a first-round draft pick (10th overall) of the parent Colorado Avalanche in the June draft, got the Rampage off and running with a bullet from the blue line just 6 minutes, 40 seconds into the game.

“I just threw the puck to the net and it went in,” said Rantanen, the draft’s top-rated European prospect who played three seasons in the Finnish pro league. “I wasn’t nervous. I’m glad I’m here. I just wanted to play.” 
The 6-foot-4, 211-pound forward started the season with the parent Avalanche, but was sent down to get playing time. 
He averaged just 9:12 in his six games with Colorado. 
“He was good enough to play with us,” Avalanche GM Joe Sakic said before the game. “But as an 18-year-old, you need to play. Coming down here, he’s going to get that opportunity.” 
“The kid can play,” Rampage coach Dean Chynoweth said. “There’s a reason why he was a first-round pick.” 
The Rampage (3-0-1-0) never trailed. They were without leading scorer Andrew Agozzino , out with an upper body injury. 
But Rantanen and Bigras more than made up for his absence. Patrick Bordeleau made it three Rampage players with multi-point nights with two assists. 
Bigras, 20, said it was a night he’ll never forget. His goal came at 12:16 of the second period. 
“That puck’s going to be hanging in a room somewhere when I’m older,” he said. 
Sam Henley , Colin Smith and Marc Andre Cliché also scored for the Rampage, who don’t play again until next Friday. 
“I liked our start,” Chynoweth said. “With the delay in the game the guys were down here early. We were preparing for two weeks for potential bad ice. 
“I really liked our defense tonight. We got each line involved in the scoring and didn’t need our power play tonight.” 
Goaltender Calvin Pickard lost his bid for a second straight shutout when Freddie Hamilton scored Stockton’s lone goal at 10:03 of the third. 
It ended Pickard’s streak of six straight scoreless periods (144 minutes, 22 seconds overall).
